             <td>
              <h2 class="left">
               <span class="articletitle" id="ContentPlaceHolder1_lblTitle">
                5 Common Tiling Mistakes The Could Ruin Your Perfect Finish
               </span>
              </h2>
             </td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
             <td class="approveEditDelete">
             </td>
            </tr>
           </table>
           4/17/2013 in category
           <b>
            "Home Improvement"
           </b>
           <img alt=" : 3.5" id="ContentPlaceHolder1_ratDisplay_imgRating" src="images/stars35.gif"/>
           <img alt="reviews" src="http://techandscience.com/Images/countviews.png" title="reviews"/>
           <b>
            2613
           </b>
          </div>
          <div class="articlebody" style="margin: 5px auto;">
           <div class="googleAdTopWrap">
            <div id="ContentPlaceHolder1_pnlAdTop">
             <script async="" src="//pagead2.googlesyndication.com/pagead/js/adsbygoogle.js">
             </script>
             <!-- ResponsiveAdBlock -->
             <ins class="adsbygoogle" data-ad-client="ca-pub-3027018399965506" data-ad-format="auto" data-ad-slot="9066958400" style="display:block">
             </ins>
             <script>
              (adsbygoogle = window.adsbygoogle || []).push({});
             </script>
            </div>
           </div>
           <p>
            <img alt="5 Common Tiling Mistakes The Could Ruin Your Perfect Finish" class="blogimg" src="/Uploads/admin/Common-Tiling-Mistakes-0417.jpg" style="width: 300px; height: 209px;"/>
            If theres one thing that you should never do when it comes to DIY, its jump straight in. Ill pick it up as I go, I hear you say. While you might think you learn better by doing, preparation is the key to any DIY project.
           </p>
           <p>
            Nowhere is that more true than when it comes to tiling rooms like your kitchen or bathroom. These five mistakes are easily made without knowing what youre doing  so take heed, avoid these and youll be well on your way to a perfect and professional-looking finish in your home!
           </p>
           <p>
            <strong>
             1. The sub-floor is unstable, uneven or not properly prepared.
            </strong>
           </p>
           <p>
            When applying tiles to a sub-floor, a good cement board or hardibacker is essential  simply pulling up carpet or existing flooring and trying to apply tiles straight to the surface is definitely not advised. Unsuitable sub flooring might not be able to carry the extra weight of the tiles, or may shift and cause cracks in grouting and tiles to come loose. An uneven sub-floor can cause tiles to shift before the adhesive and grouting has dried, as well as creating issues with lippage. Even if the sub-floor is suitable and level, it should always be washed down and completely dried to ensure its clean.
           </p>
           <p>
            <strong>
             2. Poor tile application
            </strong>
           </p>
           <p>
            If, when laying your tiles, you dont properly space them you can end up with a whole host of problems beyond the finish simply looking off. Unevenly applied tiles can cause lippage, where some tiles end up higher than others leaving you with both a dangerous tripping hazard and a finish that looks sloppy. Be sure to use battens to align your tiles properly, and tile spaces to ensure that you have even
           </p>
           <p>
            <strong>
             3. Using the wrong tile adhesive
            </strong>
           </p>
           <p>
            While tiling techniques can broadly be applicable to any room in your house, there are always special considerations needed and one particularly important one is when it comes to choosing the adhesive. If tiling somewhere like a bathroom, or around kitchen work surfaces, its vital that you use a waterproof adhesive  there are bound to be some small gaps between tiles and grouting, and issues with water getting in can cause adhesive to crack.
           </p>
           <p>
            <strong>
             4. Uneven application of adhesive.
            </strong>
           </p>
           <p>
            Its vital to remember to apply the adhesive to the sub-floor and backs of tiles as evenly as possible. Whilst the pressure from fixing the tile will likely even out any small discrepancies, any significant differences will leave you with a significant risk of tile cracking. Adhesive shrinks as it dries  therefore, any big differences in thickness will add increased pressure on the tile and will make cracking more likely.
           </p>
           <p>
            <strong>
             5. Poor forward planning!
            </strong>
           </p>
           <p>
            One of the biggest planning mistakes that people tend to makes is not buying more tiles than they need. While it might sound bizarre, if you buy just enough tiles to cover the wall or floor youre tiling then you leave yourself absolutely zero room for error. Mis-measuring an area, breakages and cutting tiles will all mean you need a few extra than you expected  its good practice to buy around 10% more than you think you need, so youre prepared. Even if your tiling is absolutely perfect, the extra will come in handy as spares should any tiles need to be replaced in future.
           </p>
           <p>
            In short, tiling a wall or
            <a href="http://techandscience.com/techblog/ShowArticle.aspx?ID=3142" target="_blank">
             floor in your home
            </a>
            shouldnt be a daunting task, but it does pay to be prepared. Having to rip up all your tiling and start again is costly, time consuming and unbelievably frustrating, so follow these tips and always ask a professional if youre unsure  theyve done it more times than you!
           </p>
           <p>
            <em>
             This post was written by Tom McShane  a professional writing and bumbling DIY klutz. With the help of advice from
             <a href="http://www.tilechoice.co.uk/" target="_blank">
              <strong>
               Tile Choice
              </strong>
             </a>
             , Tom was able to avoid these easy-to-make mistakes and get his new bathroom looking great. Although its so good now he might not ever leave it.
            </em>
           </p>
